import { useEffect, useState, useRef, useMemo, useCallback } from 'react';
import { supabase } from '@/integrations/supabase/client';
import { Node, Edge } from '@xyflow/react';
import { computePositions } from '@/services/layoutEngine';
import { getNodeBoxWidth, getNodeBoxHeight } from '@/services/nodeRenderConfig';
import { initTextMeasurer } from '@/services/textMeasure';
import { useTodayTime } from './useTodayTime';
import { graphDocumentChannel } from '@/state/graphDocumentChannel';
import { startOfDay as startOfDayFn, endOfDay as endOfDayFn } from 'date-fns';

interface GraphNode {
  id: string;
  type: string;
  position_x: number;
  position_y: number;
  label: string;
  status?: string;
  parents?: string[];
  graph?: string;
  percentage_of_parent?: number;
  createdAt?: string;
  color?: string;
}

interface GraphEdge {
  id: string;
  source_id: string;
  target_id: string;
  animated: boolean;
  style: any;
}

const buildHierarchyMap = (nodesData: any, completedNodeIds: Set<string> = new Set()) => {
  const logPrefix = '[LayoutEngine/buildHierarchyMap]';
  console.log(`${logPrefix} Running for ${Object.keys(nodesData).length} nodes.`);

  const levels: { [level: number]: string[] } = {};
  const nodeToLevel: { [nodeId: string]: number } = {};
  const nodeIdsInCurrentGraph = new Set(Object.keys(nodesData));

  // This iterative approach correctly finds the longest path to each node,
  // ensuring that siblings with different length paths leading to them are still
  // placed in the correct, furthest column. This calculates levels from R-to-L.
  const rightToLeftLevels: { [nodeId: string]: number } = {};
  let changedInPass = true;
  let iterations = 0;
  const maxIterations = Object.keys(nodesData).length + 5; // Safety break

  while (changedInPass && iterations < maxIterations) {
    changedInPass = false;
    Object.keys(nodesData).forEach(nodeId => {
      const parents = (nodesData[nodeId]?.parents || []).filter((pId: string) => nodeIdsInCurrentGraph.has(pId));

      let maxParentLevel = -1;
      // A node's level is 0 if it has no parents in the current graph.
      // Otherwise, it's 1 + the maximum level of its parents.
      if (parents.length > 0) {
        parents.forEach((pId: string) => {
          if (rightToLeftLevels[pId] !== undefined) {
            maxParentLevel = Math.max(maxParentLevel, rightToLeftLevels[pId]);
          }
        });
      }

      const newLevel = maxParentLevel + 1;
      if (rightToLeftLevels[nodeId] !== newLevel) {
        rightToLeftLevels[nodeId] = newLevel;
        changedInPass = true;
      }
    });
    iterations++;
  }

  // Now, we invert the R-to-L levels to get the correct L-to-R layout.
  const maxLevel = Math.max(0, ...Object.values(rightToLeftLevels));
  Object.entries(rightToLeftLevels).forEach(([nodeId, rtlLevel]) => {
    const finalLevel = maxLevel - rtlLevel;
    nodeToLevel[nodeId] = finalLevel;
    if (!levels[finalLevel]) levels[finalLevel] = [];
    levels[finalLevel].push(nodeId);
  });

  // Filter out columns that only contain completed nodes for counting purposes
  const activeLevels = Object.entries(levels).filter(([, nodeIds]) =>
    !nodeIds.every(id => completedNodeIds.has(id))
  );

  console.log(`${logPrefix} Final Levels (raw):`, levels);
  console.log(`${logPrefix} Active Column Count: ${activeLevels.length}`);

  return { levels, nodeToLevel, activeColumnCount: activeLevels.length };
};

export function useGraphData(selectedStartOfDay?: Date, selectedEndOfDay?: Date) {
  const { dayKey, startOfDay, endOfDay } = useTodayTime();
  const effectiveStartOfDay = selectedStartOfDay ?? startOfDay;
  const effectiveEndOfDay = selectedEndOfDay ?? endOfDay;
  const [docData, setDocData] = useState<any>(null);
  const [activeGraphId, setActiveGraphId] = useState<string>('main');
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [viewportState, setViewportState] = useState({ x: 0, y: 0, zoom: 1 });
  const [positions, setPositions] = useState<Record<string, { x: number, y: number }>>({});
  const [nodeToGraphMap, setNodeToGraphMap] = useState<Record<string, string>>({});
  const [showTodayOnly, setShowTodayOnly] = useState(true);

  const toggleShowTodayOnly = useCallback(() => {
    setShowTodayOnly((prev) => !prev);
  }, []);

  const filteredDocNodes = useMemo(() => {
    const allNodes = (docData?.nodes || {}) as Record<string, any>;
    if (!showTodayOnly) {
      return allNodes;
    }
    const startMs = effectiveStartOfDay.getTime();
    const endMs = effectiveEndOfDay.getTime();
    return Object.fromEntries(
      Object.entries(allNodes).filter(([, node]) => {
        const scheduledStart = node?.scheduled_start;
        if (!scheduledStart) return true;
        const scheduledStartMs = Date.parse(scheduledStart);
        if (Number.isNaN(scheduledStartMs)) return true;
        return scheduledStartMs >= startMs && scheduledStartMs <= endMs;
      })
    );
  }, [docData?.nodes, showTodayOnly, effectiveStartOfDay, effectiveEndOfDay]);

  const { nodes, edges } = useMemo(() => {
    if (!filteredDocNodes || Object.keys(filteredDocNodes).length === 0) return { nodes: [], edges: [] };

    const allNodes = filteredDocNodes;
    const filtered = Object.entries(allNodes).filter(([id]: [string, any]) =>
      (nodeToGraphMap[id] || 'main') === activeGraphId
    );

    const transformedNodes: Node[] = filtered.map(([key, value]: [string, any]) => ({
      id: key,
      type: value.type,
      position: positions[key] || { x: 0, y: 0 },
      data: {
        label: value.label,
        status: value.status || 'not-started',
        parents: value.parents || [],
        graph: value.graph || 'main',
        color: value.color,
      },
    }));

    const nodeIdsInGraph = new Set(transformedNodes.map(n => n.id));
    const transformedEdges: Edge[] = Object.entries(allNodes)
      .filter(([, value]: [string, any]) => value.parents && Array.isArray(value.parents))
      .flatMap(([nodeId, value]: [string, any]) =>
        value.parents.map((parentId: string, idx: number) => ({
          id: `${nodeId}-${parentId}-${idx}`,
          source: nodeId,
          target: parentId,
          animated: true,
          style: {},
        }))
      )
      .filter(e => nodeIdsInGraph.has(e.source) && nodeIdsInGraph.has(e.target));

    console.log(`[LayoutEngine] Rendering graph '${activeGraphId}' with ${transformedNodes.length} nodes.`);
    return { nodes: transformedNodes, edges: transformedEdges };
  }, [filteredDocNodes, activeGraphId, positions, nodeToGraphMap]);


  const [measuredNodes, setMeasuredNodes] = useState<{ [id: string]: { width: number; height: number } }>({});
  const [isFirstLayoutDone, setIsFirstLayoutDone] = useState(false);
  const [layoutReady, setLayoutReady] = useState(false);
  const localOperationsRef = useRef(new Set<string>());
  const [activeNodeId, setActiveNodeId] = useState<string | null>(null);
  const layoutRecalcTimerRef = useRef<any>(null);
  const didPostMeasureLayoutRef = useRef<boolean>(false);
  const measuredNodesRef = useRef(measuredNodes);
  const stabilizationTimerRef = useRef<any>(null);
  const lastStableSnapshotRef = useRef<{ [id: string]: { width: number; height: number } } | null>(null);

  const fetchGraphData = async () => {
    try {
      setLoading(true);

      // Fetch the single graph document
      const { data: docRow, error: docError } = await (supabase as any)
        .from('graph_documents')
        .select('data')
        .eq('id', 'main')
        .maybeSingle();

      if (docError) throw docError;
      const data = (docRow?.data as any) || {};
      setDocData(data);

      console.log('[Graph] Initial fetch complete. Active graph:', activeGraphId);

      const vp = data.viewport || { x: 0, y: 0, zoom: 1 };
      setViewportState({ x: Number(vp.x ?? 0), y: Number(vp.y ?? 0), zoom: Number(vp.zoom ?? 1) });
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error fetching graph data:', error);
    } finally {
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };
  const getActiveNodesData = useCallback((dataOverride?: any) => {
    const data = dataOverride ?? filteredDocNodes;
    const allNodes = data || {};
    const subsetEntries = Object.entries(allNodes).filter(([, n]: [string, any]) => (n.graph || 'main') === activeGraphId);
    const subset: any = {};
    subsetEntries.forEach(([id, n]) => {
      subset[id] = n;
    });
    return subset;
  }, [filteredDocNodes, activeGraphId]);

  // The buildGraphForActiveId function is now replaced by the useMemo hook.

  const updateNodePosition = async (_nodeId: string, _x: number, _y: number) => {
    // No-op: positions are now 100% auto-calculated
    return;
  };

  const calculateHistory = (nodes: Record<string, any>) => {
    const parentToChildrenMap: Record<string, string[]> = {};
    Object.entries(nodes).forEach(([id, node]: [string, any]) => {
      if (node.parents) {
        node.parents.forEach((pId: string) => {
          if (!parentToChildrenMap[pId]) parentToChildrenMap[pId] = [];
          parentToChildrenMap[pId].push(id);
        });
      }
    });

    const endNodes = Object.keys(nodes).filter(id => !parentToChildrenMap[id] || parentToChildrenMap[id].length === 0);
    if (endNodes.length === 0) {
      console.warn("No end nodes found, cannot calculate absolute percentages.");
      return {};
    }
    const finalGoalValue = endNodes.reduce((sum, id) => sum + (nodes[id].percentage_of_parent || 100), 0);

    const memoAbs = new Map<string, number>();
    const getAbsolutePercentage = (nodeId: string): number => {
      if (memoAbs.has(nodeId)) return memoAbs.get(nodeId)!;

      let total = 0;
      if (endNodes.includes(nodeId)) {
        total = (nodes[nodeId].percentage_of_parent || 0) / finalGoalValue * 100;
      } else {
        const children = parentToChildrenMap[nodeId] || [];
        children.forEach(childId => {
          const nodePerc = nodes[nodeId].percentage_of_parent || 0;
          total += (getAbsolutePercentage(childId) * nodePerc) / 100;
        });
      }

      memoAbs.set(nodeId, total);
      return total;
    };

    const history: Record<string, any> = {};
    const completedNodeMap: Record<string, string[]> = {};
    const allCompletedNodes = Object.entries(nodes).filter(([, n]: [string, any]) => n.status === 'completed' && n.completed_at);

    allCompletedNodes.forEach(([id, node]: [string, any]) => {
      const dateKey = new Date(node.completed_at).toISOString().split('T')[0];
      if (!completedNodeMap[dateKey]) completedNodeMap[dateKey] = [];
      completedNodeMap[dateKey].push(id);
    });

    const sortedDates = Object.keys(completedNodeMap).sort();
    let cumulativeCompletedSet = new Set<string>();
    let lastTotal = 0;

    if (sortedDates.length > 0) {
      const firstDate = new Date(sortedDates[0]);
      let currentDate = new Date(firstDate);
      const today = new Date();
      today.setHours(0, 0, 0, 0);

      while (currentDate <= today) {
        const dateKey = currentDate.toISOString().split('T')[0];
        const nodesCompletedThisDay = completedNodeMap[dateKey] || [];
        nodesCompletedThisDay.forEach(id => cumulativeCompletedSet.add(id));

        const newTotal = Array.from(cumulativeCompletedSet).reduce((sum, id) => sum + getAbsolutePercentage(id), 0);

        history[dateKey] = {
          completed_nodes: nodesCompletedThisDay,
          total_percentage_complete: newTotal,
          daily_gain: newTotal - lastTotal,
        };

        lastTotal = newTotal;
        currentDate.setDate(currentDate.getDate() + 1);
      }
    }
    return history;
  }

  const setNodeStatus = async (nodeId: string, targetStatus: 'not-started' | 'in-progress' | 'completed') => {
    try {
      const operationId = `set-status-${nodeId}-${Date.now()}`;
      localOperationsRef.current.add(operationId);

      const nextDoc = { ...(docData || {}) } as any;
      if (!nextDoc.nodes) nextDoc.nodes = {};

      nextDoc.nodes = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(nextDoc.nodes));

      const nodesToUpdate: { [key: string]: any } = {};

      if (targetStatus === 'completed') {
        const parentToChildrenMap: Record<string, string[]> = {};
        Object.entries(nextDoc.nodes).forEach(([id, node]: [string, any]) => {
          if (node.parents) {
            node.parents.forEach((pId: string) => {
              if (!parentToChildrenMap[pId]) parentToChildrenMap[pId] = [];
              parentToChildrenMap[pId].push(id);
            });
          }
        });

        const nodesToComplete = new Set<string>();
        const queue: string[] = [nodeId];

        while (queue.length > 0) {
          const currentId = queue.shift()!;
          if (nodesToComplete.has(currentId) || nextDoc.nodes[currentId]?.status === 'completed') {
            continue;
          }
          nodesToComplete.add(currentId);
          const children = parentToChildrenMap[currentId];
          if (children && Array.isArray(children)) {
            children.forEach((childId: string) => queue.push(childId));
          }
        }

        nodesToComplete.forEach(id => {
          nodesToUpdate[id] = { status: 'completed', completed_at: new Date().toISOString() };
        });
      } else {
        nodesToUpdate[nodeId] = { status: targetStatus };
        if (nextDoc.nodes[nodeId]?.completed_at) {
          nodesToUpdate[nodeId].completed_at = null;
        }
      }

      // Optimistic local update is now handled by setDocData triggering the useMemo

      Object.entries(nodesToUpdate).forEach(([id, updates]) => {
        if (!nextDoc.nodes[id]) nextDoc.nodes[id] = {};
        Object.assign(nextDoc.nodes[id], updates);
        if (updates.completed_at === null) {
          delete nextDoc.nodes[id].completed_at;
        }
      });

      // Re-calculate entire history on every status change to ensure consistency
      nextDoc.historical_progress = calculateHistory(nextDoc.nodes);

      setDocData(nextDoc);

      await calculateAutoLayout();

      const { error } = await (supabase as any)
        .from('graph_documents')
        .update({ data: nextDoc })
        .eq('id', 'main');
      if (error) throw error;

      setTimeout(() => {
        localOperationsRef.current.delete(operationId);
      }, 1000);
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error setting node status:', error);
    }
  };

  const updateNodeCompletion = async (nodeId: string) => {
    try {
      // Determine new status from current doc using three-state model
      const current = (docData as any)?.nodes?.[nodeId]?.status;
      let newStatus: 'not-started' | 'in-progress' | 'completed';
      if (current === 'in-progress') {
        newStatus = 'completed';
      } else if (current === 'completed' || current === 'complete') {
        newStatus = 'not-started';
      } else {
        newStatus = 'in-progress';
      }

      // Delegate the actual update to setNodeStatus to ensure cascading logic is applied
      await setNodeStatus(nodeId, newStatus);
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error updating node completion:', error);
    }
  };

  const deleteNode = async (nodeId: string) => {
    try {
      const nextDoc = { ...(docData || {}) } as any;
      if (nextDoc.nodes) {
        const parentToChildrenMap: Record<string, string[]> = {};
        Object.entries(nextDoc.nodes).forEach(([id, node]: [string, any]) => {
          if (node.parents) {
            node.parents.forEach((pId: string) => {
              if (!parentToChildrenMap[pId]) parentToChildrenMap[pId] = [];
              parentToChildrenMap[pId].push(id);
            });
          }
        });

        const nodesToDelete = new Set<string>();
        const queue: string[] = [nodeId];

        while (queue.length > 0) {
          const currentId = queue.shift()!;
          if (nodesToDelete.has(currentId)) continue;
          nodesToDelete.add(currentId);

          const children = parentToChildrenMap[currentId] || [];
          children.forEach(childId => queue.push(childId));
        }

        nodesToDelete.forEach(id => {
          delete nextDoc.nodes[id];
        });

        // This secondary pass is to clean up any dangling parent references
        // from nodes that were NOT part of the deletion chain.
        Object.values(nextDoc.nodes).forEach((node: any) => {
          if (node.parents && Array.isArray(node.parents)) {
            node.parents = node.parents.filter((p: string) => !nodesToDelete.has(p));
          }
        });
      }

      // Optimistic local state
      setDocData(nextDoc);
      // setNodes(prev => prev.filter(n => n.id !== nodeId)); // useMemo handles this
      // setEdges(prev => prev.filter(e => e.source !== nodeId && e.target !== nodeId)); // useMemo handles this

      const { error } = await (supabase as any)
        .from('graph_documents')
        .update({ data: nextDoc })
        .eq('id', 'main');
      if (error) throw error;

      // Trigger auto-layout after deletion
      await calculateAutoLayout();
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error deleting node:', error);
    }
  };

  // Deprecated: active node removed. Keep a no-op for compatibility.
  const updateActiveNode = async (_nodeId: string | null) => {
    setActiveNodeId(null);
    return;
  };

  const updateViewportState = async (x: number, y: number, zoom: number) => {
    try {
      const newViewportState = { x, y, zoom };
      setViewportState(newViewportState);
      console.log('[Viewport] updateViewportState', newViewportState);

      const nextDoc = { ...(docData || {}) } as any;
      nextDoc.viewport = { x, y, zoom };
      setDocData(nextDoc);

      const { error } = await (supabase as any)
        .from('graph_documents')
        .update({ data: nextDoc })
        .eq('id', 'main');

      if (error) throw error;
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error updating viewport state:', error);
    }
  };

  // Auto-layout configuration
  const GAP_DISTANCE = 150; // Fixed gap between slice edges (right edge of previous, left edge of next)
  const VERTICAL_NODE_SPACING = 120;
  const MEASUREMENT_EPSILON = 0.5; // flow units (~px in flow coords)
  const MAX_SANE_WIDTH = 500; // ignore pre-fit oversized mobile measurements
  const MAX_SANE_HEIGHT = 300;

  // Estimators using canvas-based measurement and config
  const getNodeWidth = (nodeId: string, label: string) => {
    const nodeType = (docData?.nodes?.[nodeId]?.type) || 'objectiveNode';
    return getNodeBoxWidth(nodeType, label || '');
  };
  const getNodeHeight = (nodeId: string) => {
    // Prefer actual measured height if available
    const measuredH = measuredNodes[nodeId]?.height;
    if (typeof measuredH === 'number' && measuredH > 0) return measuredH;
    const nodeType = (docData?.nodes?.[nodeId]?.type) || 'objectiveNode';
    return getNodeBoxHeight(nodeType);
  };

  // Keep a ref to measuredNodes for timers/RAF checks
  useEffect(() => {
    measuredNodesRef.current = measuredNodes;
  }, [measuredNodes]);

  // buildHierarchyMap moved to module scope

  const calculateSlicePositions = (levels: { [level: number]: string[] }, nodesData: any) => {
    const slices: { [level: number]: { leftmost: number; rightmost: number; midpoint: number; width: number } } = {};

    // Determine slice widths (max node width per slice)
    const sortedLevels = Object.keys(levels).map(Number).sort((a, b) => a - b);
    const sliceWidths: { [level: number]: number } = {};
    for (const level of sortedLevels) {
      const nodeIds = levels[level];
      let maxWidth = 0;
      nodeIds.forEach(nodeId => {
        const width = getNodeWidth(nodeId, nodesData[nodeId].label);
        maxWidth = Math.max(maxWidth, width);
      });
      sliceWidths[level] = maxWidth;
    }

    // Calculate slice midpoints using the required formula:
    // nextMid = prevMid + (prevWidth/2) + GAP_DISTANCE + (nextWidth/2)
    sortedLevels.forEach((level, index) => {
      const width = sliceWidths[level] || 0;
      let midpoint = 0;
      if (index === 0) {
        // Anchor first slice midpoint at 0 for determinism
        midpoint = 0;
      } else {
        const prevLevel = sortedLevels[index - 1];
        const prev = slices[prevLevel];
        const prevWidth = sliceWidths[prevLevel] || 0;
        midpoint = prev.midpoint + (prevWidth / 2) + GAP_DISTANCE + (width / 2);
      }
      const leftmost = midpoint - (width / 2);
      const rightmost = leftmost + width;
      slices[level] = { leftmost, rightmost, midpoint, width };
      console.log(`Slice ${level}: midpoint=${midpoint}, width=${width}, leftmost=${leftmost}, rightmost=${rightmost}`);
    });

    return slices;
  };

  const findDensestColumn = (levels: { [level: number]: string[] }) => {
    let maxCount = 0;
    let densestLevel = 0;

    Object.entries(levels).forEach(([level, nodes]) => {
      if (nodes.length > maxCount) {
        maxCount = nodes.length;
        densestLevel = parseInt(level);
      }
    });

    return densestLevel;
  };

  const calculateAutoLayout = useCallback(async () => {
    const activeNodesData = getActiveNodesData();
    if (!activeNodesData || Object.keys(activeNodesData).length === 0) {
      console.log('No nodes data available for auto-layout');
      return;
    }

    // First, build hierarchy for all active nodes to identify completed levels
    const fullHierarchy = buildHierarchyMap(activeNodesData);
    const completedLevelNumbers = Object.entries(fullHierarchy.levels)
      .filter(([_, nodeIds]) =>
        nodeIds.every(id => activeNodesData[id]?.status === 'completed')
      )
      .map(([level]) => parseInt(level));

    const nodesData = activeNodesData;
    console.log('Calculating auto-layout for nodes:', Object.keys(nodesData));
    const activeIds = Object.keys(nodesData);
    console.log('Measured nodes (subset of active graph):', Object.fromEntries(Object.entries(measuredNodes).filter(([id]) => activeIds.includes(id))));

    const { levels, nodeToLevel } = buildHierarchyMap(nodesData);
    console.log('Hierarchy levels:', levels);
    console.log('Node to level mapping:', nodeToLevel);

    const newPositions = computePositions({
      nodesData,
      levels,
      nodeToLevel,
      getNodeWidth,
      getNodeHeight,
      gapDistance: GAP_DISTANCE,
      verticalSpacing: VERTICAL_NODE_SPACING,
    });
    console.log('[Layout] Positions computed (top-left):', newPositions);

    setPositions(newPositions);

    // Step 5: Update database (but don't store positions since auto-layout handles them)
    // We can remove position storage since auto-layout calculates them
    console.log('Auto-layout calculation complete');
    setLayoutReady(true);
  }, [getActiveNodesData, measuredNodes, GAP_DISTANCE, VERTICAL_NODE_SPACING]);

  const calculateAndRecordHistoricalProgress = async () => {
    if (!docData?.nodes) return;
    const newHistory = calculateHistory(docData.nodes);

    // Avoids a write if history hasn't changed
    if (JSON.stringify(newHistory) !== JSON.stringify(docData.historical_progress || {})) {
      const nextDoc = { ...docData, historical_progress: newHistory };
      setDocData(nextDoc);
      await supabase.from('graph_documents').update({ data: nextDoc }).eq('id', 'main');
    }
  };

  const addRelationship = async (sourceId: string, targetId: string) => {
    try {
      const operationId = `edge-${sourceId}-${targetId}-${Date.now()}`;
      console.log('Starting addRelationship operation:', operationId);
      localOperationsRef.current.add(operationId);

      const nextDoc = { ...(docData || {}) } as any;
      if (!nextDoc.nodes) {
        nextDoc.nodes = {};
      }

      // Check if relationship already exists
      const targetNode = nextDoc.nodes[targetId];
      if (targetNode && !(targetNode.parents || []).includes(sourceId)) {
        nextDoc.nodes[targetId] = { ...targetNode, parents: [...(targetNode.parents || []), sourceId] };
        setDocData(nextDoc);

        const { error } = await (supabase as any)
          .from('graph_documents')
          .update({ data: nextDoc })
          .eq('id', 'main');
        if (error) throw error;

        // Trigger auto-layout after relationship change
        await calculateAutoLayout();
        // Rebuild graph view in case active graph subset changed
        // buildGraphForActiveId(nextDoc, activeGraphId); // useMemo handles this
      }

      setTimeout(() => {
        console.log('Removing operation from tracking:', operationId);
        localOperationsRef.current.delete(operationId);
      }, 2000);
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error adding relationship:', error);
    }
  };

  useEffect(() => {
    console.log('useGraphData useEffect running');
    initTextMeasurer();
    fetchGraphData().then(() => {
      // Intentionally not awaiting this background task
      calculateAndRecordHistoricalProgress();
    });

    // Realtime: listen for changes to graph_documents id 'main'
    const channel = (supabase as any)
      .channel('graph_documents_changes')
      .on('postgres_changes', { event: '*', schema: 'public', table: 'graph_documents', filter: 'id=eq.main' }, (payload: any) => {
        try {
          // Skip handling if this client just wrote
          if (localOperationsRef.current.size > 0) return;
          const next = payload?.new?.data;
          if (next) {
            setDocData(next);
            // buildGraphForActiveId(next, activeGraphId); // useMemo handles this
            setLayoutReady(false);
            setIsFirstLayoutDone(false);
            // Compute layout after short microtask
            setTimeout(() => {
              try { calculateAutoLayout(); } catch (e) { console.error('Realtime layout error', e); }
            }, 0);
          }
        } catch (e) {
          console.error('Realtime change handling error', e);
        }
      })
      .subscribe();

    return () => {
      try { (supabase as any).removeChannel(channel); } catch { }
    };
  }, []);

  useEffect(() => {
    const unsubscribe = graphDocumentChannel.subscribe((update) => {
      if (!update?.document) return;
      console.log('[GraphData] Applying external graph update from', update.source, update.versionId);
      setDocData(update.document);
      setLayoutReady(false);
      setIsFirstLayoutDone(false);
      setTimeout(() => {
        try { calculateAutoLayout(); } catch (error) { console.error('[GraphData] External layout error', error); }
      }, 0);
    });
    return () => {
      unsubscribe();
    };
  }, [calculateAutoLayout]);

  useEffect(() => {
    if (docData?.nodes) {
      const newMap = determineNodeGraphs(docData.nodes);
      setNodeToGraphMap(newMap);
    }
  }, [docData?.nodes]);

  useEffect(() => {
    if (!docData?.nodes) return;

    const today = new Date().toISOString().split('T')[0];
    const yesterday = new Date(new Date().setDate(new Date().getDate() - 1)).toISOString().split('T')[0];
    const nodesToPatch: Record<string, any> = {};

    let needsUpdate = false;
    Object.entries(docData.nodes).forEach(([id, node]: [string, any]) => {
      // Rule 1: Yesterday's incomplete tasks get reset
      if (node.scheduled_start?.startsWith(yesterday) && node.status === 'in-progress') {
        nodesToPatch[id] = { ...node, status: 'not-started' };
        needsUpdate = true;
      }
      // Rule 2: Today's scheduled tasks get started
      if (node.scheduled_start?.startsWith(today) && node.status === 'not-started') {
        nodesToPatch[id] = { ...node, status: 'in-progress' };
        needsUpdate = true;
      }
    });

    if (needsUpdate) {
      const nextDoc = {
        ...docData,
        nodes: {
          ...docData.nodes,
          ...nodesToPatch,
        }
      };
      setDocData(nextDoc);
      setNodeToGraphMap(determineNodeGraphs(nextDoc.nodes));
      supabase.from('graph_documents').update({ data: nextDoc }).eq('id', 'main').then(({ error }) => {
        if (error) console.error("Error in midnight update:", error);
      });
    }
  }, [dayKey]); // Triggered by the useTodayTime hook

  // Handle node measurements from React Flow
  const handleNodeMeasure = (nodeId: string, width: number, height: number) => {
    // Retain for optional debugging; no-op for layout
    return;
  };

  // Reset first layout flag when data changes significantly
  useEffect(() => {
    if (docData?.nodes) {
      const nodeIds = Object.keys(docData.nodes);
      const measuredIds = Object.keys(measuredNodes);
      const hasUnmeasuredNodes = nodeIds.some(id => !measuredIds.includes(id));

      if (hasUnmeasuredNodes) {
        setIsFirstLayoutDone(false);
        setLayoutReady(false);
        didPostMeasureLayoutRef.current = false;
        lastStableSnapshotRef.current = null;
        if (stabilizationTimerRef.current) {
          clearTimeout(stabilizationTimerRef.current);
          stabilizationTimerRef.current = null;
        }
      }
    }
  }, [docData?.nodes]);

  // Rebuild graph whenever activeGraphId changes
  useEffect(() => {
    if (docData) {
      console.log('[Graph] activeGraphId changed to', activeGraphId, '- rebuilding graph');
      // buildGraphForActiveId(docData, activeGraphId); // useMemo handles this
      setLayoutReady(false);
      setIsFirstLayoutDone(false);
      didPostMeasureLayoutRef.current = false;
      lastStableSnapshotRef.current = null;
      if (stabilizationTimerRef.current) {
        clearTimeout(stabilizationTimerRef.current);
        stabilizationTimerRef.current = null;
      }
      // Seed an initial layout quickly using fallback sizes to ensure nodes mount and measure
      setTimeout(() => {
        try {
          console.log('[Layout] Seeding initial layout for graph', activeGraphId);
          calculateAutoLayout();
        } catch (e) {
          console.error('[Layout] Seed layout error', e);
        }
      }, 0);
      // Full stabilized layout will follow when measurements settle
    }
  }, [activeGraphId]);

  // This can likely be simplified or removed as well, relying on docData changes.
  useEffect(() => {
    if (!docData?.nodes) return;
    const nodesData = getActiveNodesData();
    if (Object.keys(nodesData).length === 0) return;
    console.log('[Layout] Immediate layout for graph', activeGraphId);
    calculateAutoLayout();
    setIsFirstLayoutDone(true);
    setLayoutReady(true);
  }, [activeGraphId, docData?.nodes, showTodayOnly, calculateAutoLayout, getActiveNodesData]);


  return {
    nodes,
    edges,
    loading,
    activeNodeId,
    activeGraphId,
    viewportState,
    docData,
    layoutReady,
    measuredNodes,
    nodeToGraphMap,
    nodesById: filteredDocNodes,

    updateNodePosition,
    updateNodeCompletion,
    setNodeStatus,
    updateActiveNode,
    setActiveGraphId,
    updateViewportState,
    deleteNode,
    addRelationship,
    calculateAutoLayout,
    refetch: fetchGraphData,
    handleNodeMeasure,
    showTodayOnly,
    toggleShowTodayOnly,
  };
}

const determineNodeGraphs = (allNodes: Record<string, any>): Record<string, string> => {
  const nodeToGraphMap: Record<string, string> = {};
  if (!allNodes || Object.keys(allNodes).length === 0) {
    return nodeToGraphMap;
  }
  const logPrefix = '[LayoutEngine/determineNodeGraphs]';
  console.log(`${logPrefix} Starting graph determination...`);

  const sortedNodeIds = Object.keys(allNodes).sort((a, b) => {
    const dateA = new Date(allNodes[a]?.createdAt || 0).getTime();
    const dateB = new Date(allNodes[b]?.createdAt || 0).getTime();
    return dateA - dateB;
  });
  console.log(`${logPrefix} Nodes sorted by createdAt:`, sortedNodeIds);

  const completedNodeIds = new Set(Object.entries(allNodes)
    .filter(([, node]) => node.status === 'completed')
    .map(([id]) => id));

  const tempGraphViews: { [graphId: string]: Set<string> } = { 'main': new Set() };

  for (const nodeId of sortedNodeIds) {
    const node = allNodes[nodeId];
    const parentId = (node.parents || [])[0];

    let assignedGraphId = 'main';
    if (parentId && nodeToGraphMap[parentId]) {
      assignedGraphId = nodeToGraphMap[parentId];
    }
    console.log(`${logPrefix} Processing node '${nodeId}': initial assignedGraph='${assignedGraphId}'`);

    if (!tempGraphViews[assignedGraphId]) {
      tempGraphViews[assignedGraphId] = new Set();
    }
    tempGraphViews[assignedGraphId].add(nodeId);

    const nodesForLayoutCheck = Object.fromEntries(
      Object.entries(allNodes).filter(([id]) => tempGraphViews[assignedGraphId].has(id))
    );

    const { activeColumnCount } = buildHierarchyMap(nodesForLayoutCheck, completedNodeIds);

    console.log(`${logPrefix} ... in graph '${assignedGraphId}', active column count is now ${activeColumnCount}`);

    if (activeColumnCount > 6 && parentId) {
      console.log(`${logPrefix} ... NESTING! Active column count > 6. Moving '${nodeId}' to subgraph of '${parentId}'`);
      // Nest the node
      assignedGraphId = parentId;
      // Remove from old graph view and add to new one
      for (const key in tempGraphViews) {
        if (tempGraphViews[key].has(nodeId)) {
          tempGraphViews[key].delete(nodeId);
        }
      }
      if (!tempGraphViews[assignedGraphId]) {
        tempGraphViews[assignedGraphId] = new Set();
      }
      tempGraphViews[assignedGraphId].add(nodeId);
    }
    nodeToGraphMap[nodeId] = assignedGraphId;
  }
  console.log(`${logPrefix} Final node-to-graph map:`, nodeToGraphMap);
  return nodeToGraphMap;
};

Implemented day navigation across the graph experience:

- Added a shared `viewedDate` state in `CausalGraph`, with next/prev/today handlers and a popover date picker. These controls sit in a redesigned `DailyCalendarPanel` header (left/right arrows, clickable date button, “Today” reset).
- `DailyTaskPanel` and `DailyCalendarPanel` now take the selected day range and filter items accordingly.
- Progress and stats components highlight the selected day instead of hard-coded “Today” logic.
- `useGraphData` accepts external start/end-of-day bounds and adjusts node filtering/layout for the currently viewed date, keeping the “today-only” toggle aligned with the selected day.

This keeps all panels, stats, and the node filter in sync as you browse between days.

**Cursor**

You've diagnosed the problem perfectly. The AI is learning from an incomplete context, which is leading it to develop the bad habit of saying it will call a tool without actually doing so.

Here is a breakdown of the issue and the plan to fix it, confirming we are on the same page.

### The Problem: Incomplete Context Creates Bad Habits

1.  **Missing Evidence in History**: When the frontend sends a request to the AI model, it includes the previous messages to provide conversational context. However, as you've pointed out, it's only sending the *human* and *AI text responses*. It is omitting the crucial `tool_calls` and `tool_results` that occurred in those past turns.
2.  **AI Learns the Wrong Pattern**: The AI sees a history that looks like this:
    *   **User**: "Do X."
    *   **AI (Previous Turn)**: "Okay, I will do X." `[Tool Call is made here, but not sent in next request]`
    *   **AI (Previous Turn)**: "I have successfully done X." `[Tool Result is received, but not sent]`
    *   **User (Current Turn)**: "Now do Y."
3.  **Faulty Inference**: From this incomplete history, the AI incorrectly concludes that the correct pattern is to simply *state* that it has completed an action, because it never sees the evidence of the tool call that actually performed the action. It learns to mimic the chat transcript, not the underlying action.

### The Plan: Reconstructing the Full Context

To fix this, we need to modify the frontend to send the complete history, including all tool-related messages, in the format the AI model expects.

1.  **Identify the Code to Change**: I will start by locating the exact part of the frontend code responsible for constructing the `messages` array that is sent to the OpenRouter API. This is likely within the main chat component, `src/components/chat/ChatLayout.tsx` or a related hook.
2.  **Modify the Message History**:
    *   I will update this logic to iterate through the entire message history.
    *   For each message from the assistant, I will check if it contains tool calls.
    *   If it does, I will format and include them in the history using the `tool_calls` array, which is the standard format for representing tool invocations.
    *   Similarly, I will ensure that for every `tool_calls` message, there is a corresponding `tool_results` message that provides the output of that tool call.
3.  **Ensure Correct Formatting**: The final structure of the `messages` array sent to the API will now correctly represent the full sequence of events, like so:
    *   `{ "role": "user", "content": "Do X." }`
    *   `{ "role": "assistant", "content": "Okay, I will do X.", "tool_calls": [...] }`
    *   `{ "role": "tool", "tool_call_id": "...", "content": "{...result}" }`
    *   `{ "role": "assistant", "content": "I have successfully done X." }`

By implementing this, we will provide the AI with a complete and accurate context window. It will see not only the conversation but also the *proof* of the actions taken, reinforcing the correct pattern of calling tools when requested.

Currently, the frontend is failing to do this. When constructing the message history for a new API request, it correctly includes the text from previous turns but **it omits the tool call and tool result messages from that history**. The only tool call information being sent is for the *current* turn, not for any previous turns in the context window.

It is therefore learning an incorrect pattern: to simply *say* it has called a tool, without actually invoking it. This fundamentally breaks its ability to perform actions and must be corrected.

The application's chat interface communicates with a large language model via the OpenRouter API. For the AI to function correctly, it must receive a complete history of the conversation, including not just the text of the user and assistant messages, but also the full context of any tools that were called and the results they returned.

Currently, the frontend is failing to do this. When constructing the message history for a new API request, it correctly includes the text from previous turns but **it omits the tool call and tool result messages from that history**. The only tool call information being sent is for the *current* turn, not for any previous turns in the context window.

This creates a dangerously misleading context for the AI. The AI sees a history where it appears to "talk about" calling tools but never actually sees the evidence of the tool calls themselves or their results. It is therefore learning an incorrect pattern: to simply *say* it has called a tool, without actually invoking it. This fundamentally breaks its ability to perform actions and must be corrected.

### Your Directive: Implement Correct and Complete History Serialization

Your mission is to modify the frontend codebase to ensure that the entire, unabridged history of the conversation is correctly formatted and sent with every API request.

**This is the 'what' that must be accomplished:**

You must find the logic responsible for preparing the message history payload and re-implement it to conform to the standardized, conventional paradigm for representing tool-use conversations.

1.  **Preserve All Tool-Related Messages:** The message history sent to the model must include every `tool_calls` invocation from the assistant and every corresponding `tool_results` message. These are not to be discarded.
2.  **Adhere to the Correct Format:** Research and confirm the industry-standard format for including tool calls and results in a message history array. While you should verify this yourself, the paradigm generally involves a sequence of messages with distinct roles (`user`, `assistant`, `tool`). Ensure your implementation strictly adheres to this established convention. The data is already present and correct in the application's database and UI; your focus is solely on the serialization of this data for the API request.
3.  **Ensure Contextual Integrity:** The final output must be a perfect, sequential representation of the conversation, allowing the AI to understand the full context of "I decided to call a tool," "I called the tool," "Here is what the tool returned," and "Now I will respond based on that result."

Again, approach this with the mindset that correctness is the only acceptable outcome. Think through the data flow, the required data transformations, and the final structure of the API payload. Consider how to best integrate your changes into the existing codebase in a clean and maintainable way. We are counting on you to not just solve the bug, but to solve it with an impeccable level of quality and foresight.

**Cursor**

Excellent question. It gets to the very heart of the data architecture.

To answer your direct question: **No, there is no nesting paradigm in the current JSONB object.**

The current structure is completely flat and relational, defined by reference. Here’s exactly how it works:

1.  The JSONB object has a single top-level key called `"nodes"`.
2.  The value of `"nodes"` is a flat dictionary (or map), where every key is a unique `nodeId` string.
3.  The relationship between nodes is defined *only* from child to parent. Each node object has a `"parents"` array that contains the string IDs of its parent nodes.

There is no `"children"` array, and no node is nested inside another. All nodes, regardless of their position in the hierarchy, exist at the same level within the main `"nodes"` map.

Here is a simplified example to illustrate:

```json
{
  "nodes": {
    "live_forever": {
      "label": "Live Forever",
      "parents": []
    },
    "health": {
      "label": "Health & Wellbeing",
      "parents": ["live_forever"]
    },
    "workout": {
      "label": "Workout Today",
      "parents": ["health"]
    }
  }
}
```

In this structure, the system knows `"workout"` is a child of `"health"` because the `"workout"` node explicitly lists `"health"` in its `"parents"` array. The entire graph is reconstructed by resolving these references, not by traversing a nested structure.

```json
{
  "nodes": {
    "live_forever": {
      "label": "Live Forever",
      "parents": []
    },
    "health": {
      "label": "Health & Wellbeing",
      "parents": ["live_forever"]
    },
    "workout": {
      "label": "Workout Today",
      "parents": ["health"]
    }
  }
}
```

**Cursor**

Excellent question. You're weighing a fundamental data modeling decision. Let's break down the trade-offs between the two approaches: a relational (key-based) system versus a nested (hierarchical) one.

### The Two Paradigms

1.  **Relational (Key-based):** This is the current system for parent-child relationships. All nodes live in a single, flat `nodes` map. A relationship is defined by a *pointer*. A subnode would just be another node in the main map, but it would have a property like `subgraphOf: "parent_node_id"` that the UI uses to group it.
2.  **Nested (Hierarchical):** In this model, the JSON structure itself would define the relationship. A subnode object would be physically nested inside a `subnodes` array or map within its parent node object.

Here’s a detailed look at the pros and cons of each.

---

### Approach 1: Relational / Key-Based (Current Paradigm)

**How it works:** All nodes are peers in a single map. A `subgraphOf` key tells the UI how to render them.

```json
{
  "nodes": {
    "parent_A": { "label": "Parent A" },
    "sub_B":    { "label": "Sub B", "subgraphOf": "parent_A" },
    "sub_C":    { "label": "Sub C", "subgraphOf": "parent_A" }
  }
}
```

#### ✅ Pros:

1.  **Query Simplicity & Performance:** This is the biggest advantage. You can find *any node* in the graph with a single, fast lookup: `nodes['some_id']`. There is no need to traverse a complex, nested structure to find a node. This is critical for performance as the graph grows.
2.  **Structural Consistency:** Every node is a first-class citizen. Code that iterates over all nodes (for searching, validation, or layout calculation) is simple and non-recursive. It doesn't need special logic to handle nested nodes.
3.  **Ease of Updates (JSON Patch):** The current `patch_graph_document` tool relies on RFC 6902 JSON Patch. These patches work best with flat structures. A path to update a subnode's status is simple: `/nodes/sub_B/status`. In a nested world, it becomes `/nodes/parent_A/subnodes/sub_B/status`, which is much harder for the AI to construct correctly and more brittle if `sub_B` is ever moved.
4.  **Flexibility:** This model easily supports many-to-many relationships. While we may not need it now, it's trivial to imagine a scenario where a single node appears in multiple subgraphs. A relational model handles this, whereas a nested model would require duplicating the data, which is a major anti-pattern.

#### ❌ Cons:

1.  **Less Intuitive Readability:** For a human inspecting the raw JSON, the subnode relationship isn't immediately obvious from the structure. You have to see the `subgraphOf` key and mentally make the connection.
2.  **Client-Side "Joins":** The rendering logic has to do more work. To display a subgraph, the UI must first get the parent, then iterate through *all other nodes* to find the ones where `subgraphOf` matches the parent's ID. This is effectively a "join" operation performed on the client.

---

### Approach 2: Nested / Hierarchical

**How it works:** Subnodes are literally inside their parent's object.

```json
{
  "nodes": {
    "parent_A": {
      "label": "Parent A",
      "subnodes": {
        "sub_B": { "label": "Sub B" },
        "sub_C": { "label": "Sub C" }
      }
    }
  }
}
```

#### ✅ Pros:

1.  **Intuitive Structure:** This is the most human-readable format. It's a natural tree, and the grouping is visually obvious.
2.  **Data Co-location:** When you fetch `parent_A`, you automatically get all of its subnodes. You don't need a second step to find them. This is efficient *if and only if* you always need the subnodes whenever you have the parent.

#### ❌ Cons:

1.  **Difficulty of Node Discovery:** This is a critical flaw for our use case. How do you find `sub_B` if you only know its ID? You can't do a direct lookup. You would have to iterate through every top-level node and then recursively search through all of their `subnodes` maps. This is extremely inefficient and complex.
2.  **Massive Patching Complexity:** As mentioned, JSON Patch paths become very difficult. Moving `sub_B` to a new parent would require a complex, multi-step patch (a `remove` from the old path and an `add` to the new one) instead of a simple `replace` on a single key. This adds significant burden on the AI.
3.  **Recursive Logic Required:** Any function that needs to operate on all nodes (search, validation, applying a style to all nodes of a certain type) must now be written recursively to handle the nesting. This is more complex and error-prone than a simple loop.
4.  **Inflexibility:** This model makes it impossible for a node to belong to more than one subgraph without data duplication.

---

### Recommendation

**Stick with the relational, key-based approach.**

While the nested model is tempting for its readability, its cons are severe technical blockers for this specific application. The flat, relational structure is far more scalable, performant, and robust. It aligns perfectly with the tools we are already using (especially JSON Patch) and keeps the logic for finding and updating nodes dead simple.

The main downside—the need for client-side "joins"—is a very standard and manageable problem that we have already solved with the `nodeToGraphMap` and other derived data structures in the `useGraphData` hook. It's a small price to pay for the immense architectural advantages of a flat data model.

```json
{
  "nodes": {
    "parent_A": { "label": "Parent A" },
    "sub_B":    { "label": "Sub B", "subgraphOf": "parent_A" },
    "sub_C":    { "label": "Sub C", "subgraphOf": "parent_A" }
  }
}
```

```json
{
  "nodes": {
    "parent_A": {
      "label": "Parent A",
      "subnodes": {
        "sub_B": { "label": "Sub B" },
        "sub_C": { "label": "Sub C" }
      }
    }
  }
}
```

I'll scan the worker's tool implementations and the frontend's OpenRouter request composition to ground the answer in actual code. Then I'll propose how to reshape tool responses for hierarchical clarity while preserving the flat JSONB model.

Short answer: today the worker returns flat maps; the frontend sends them as-is. We can add an extra hierarchical projection to all tool responses (no schema change), so the LLM gets a tree that mirrors the UI relationships, while we keep the JSONB model flat.

What I confirmed in code
- Worker tools (remote-mcp-server-authless/src/index.ts):
  - get_graph_structure returns a flat subset in structure: { nodeId -> node }.
  - patch_graph_document returns result: <entire doc> as a flat map.
  - No nested/tree shape is returned.
- Frontend OpenRouter composition (src/components/chat/ChatPane.tsx, src/services/openRouter.ts):
  - When calling the model, we build conversationMessages from historyChain.map(({ role, content })), which omits past tool_calls/tool results. Only the current turn’s tool_calls + tool result messages are appended inside the iterative loop. This is the separate history bug we’re addressing in the other track.

Plan to reduce LLM cognitive load via hierarchical responses (additive, backwards-compatible)
- Keep DB and internal model flat (parents arrays; optional graph field). We do not change Supabase schema.
- Add a derived tree to tool responses so the LLM can reason over structure without recomputing joins:
  - Build a parentId -> childrenIds map from the flat nodes.
  - Produce a nested tree with children arrays starting from selected roots (or inferred).
  - Keep all existing fields so no existing caller breaks.

Concretely, for worker responses:
- get_graph_structure (start_node_id, depth):
  - Continue returning:
    - success, current_date, score_context, structure: <flat subset>
  - Add:
    - tree: {
        roots: [<root ids>],  // usually [start_node_id] if present, else nodes in subset with no parents in subset
        nodes: { id: NodeTree } // NodeTree: { id, label, status, color?, parents, children: [NodeTree], subnodes?: NodeTree[] }
      }
    - legend: { orientation: "children", note: "children derived from parents references" }
  - Optional: subgraphs: map of containerId -> [subnodeIds], computed from node.graph === containerId (if present).
- get_todays_context:
  - Keep current payload (success, current_date, score_context, context: flat subset).
  - Add tree as above (roots: inferred from items in today’s subset).
- patch_graph_document:
  - Keep current result.
  - Add projection:
    - tree_main: forest of entire graph for quick high-level reasoning (or omit if payload too large; if size is big, include roots only and allow a tool flag to include_full_tree).

The core principle is: **The data returned to the AI should reflect the visual hierarchy a user sees.**

Here's the plan, broken down by tool. In all cases, the `"parents"` array remains the source of truth, and we are only changing the JSON *shape* of the response, not the data itself.

### 1. `get_graph_structure`

*   **Current Response:** A flat map of nodes called `"structure"`.
    ```json
    { "structure": { "nodeA": {...}, "nodeB": { "parents": ["nodeA"] } } }
    ```
*   **Problem:** The AI has to read the `"parents"` array of every node to understand that B is a child of A.
*   **Proposed Change:** I will transform the flat `"structure"` map into a nested JSON object that mirrors the parent-child relationships. The root nodes of the requested graph section will be the top-level keys. Their children will be nested inside a `"children"` map within their parent's object.

*   **New Response Shape:**
    ```json
    {
      "structure": {
        "nodeA": {
          "label": "Parent A",
          "parents": [],
          "children": {
            "nodeB": {
              "label": "Child B",
              "parents": ["nodeA"],
              "children": {} // Empty if no children
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }
    ```
    To achieve this, I will add a server-side helper function that:
    1.  Builds a `parent -> [children]` map.
    2.  Recursively constructs the nested `structure` object, starting from the root nodes of the selection.

### 2. `get_todays_context`

*   **Current Response:** A flat map called `"context"` containing only today's relevant nodes.
*   **Problem:** Same as above. Relationships are not immediately obvious from the structure.
*   **Proposed Change:** Identical to `get_graph_structure`. I will apply the same hierarchical transformation to the `"context"` object. The root nodes will be the items in today's context that have no parents *within that same context*.

*   **New Response Shape:**
    ```json

      "context": {
        "today_root_task": {
          "label": "Today's Main Task",

      }

            }

      }
    }
    ```

Your objective is to fundamentally reshape the data structures returned by the MCP tools to improve the AI's ability to reason about the graph's hierarchy. This is a critical architectural refinement, and it is imperative that you execute it with the highest degree of precision, diligence, and foresight. Your goal is not merely to complete the task, but to implement it so correctly and robustly that it becomes a foundational improvement for all future interactions. Take all the time you need to think, plan, and verify. We are seeking a solution that is not just functional, but demonstrably correct and elegant.

### The Core Problem: Flat Data Hides Relationships

Currently, all MCP tools that return a set of graph nodes (e.g., `get_graph_structure`, `get_todays_context`) do so as a simple, flat map of `nodeId` to `nodeObject`. While this is efficient for storage, it forces the AI to perform complex, multi-step reasoning to understand the graph's structure. To know that Node B is a child of Node A, it must scan the entire list of nodes and inspect their individual `"parents"` arrays.

This imposes an unnecessary cognitive load on the AI and obscures the very relationships that the graph UI is designed to make intuitive. We are failing to transit the visual clarity of the graph through to the AI that reasons over it.

### Your Directive: Return Hierarchically Structured Data

Your mission is to modify the response format of all relevant MCP tools to present node collections in a nested, hierarchical structure that mirrors the visual parent-child relationships. The source of truth for relationships remains the `"parents"` array in the flat data model; you are simply creating a different *projection* of that data in the tool's output.

**This is the 'what' that must be accomplished:**

For every tool that returns a collection of graph nodes, you must transform that collection from a flat map into a nested JSON object before sending it as a response.

1.  **Identify All Relevant Tools:** You must audit every MCP tool in the worker and identify all endpoints that return a collection of graph nodes. This includes, but is not limited to, `get_graph_structure`, `get_todays_context`, and `patch_graph_document`.
2.  **Implement the Hierarchical Transformation:**
    *   The flat map of nodes must be converted into a nested structure where each parent node contains a `"children"` key.
    *   The value of this `"children"` key will be a map containing the full objects of its immediate children.
    *   This nesting must be applied recursively, creating a complete tree structure that represents the portion of the graph being returned.
    *   The top level of the new structure should contain only the root nodes of the selection (i.e., the nodes that have no parents *within the returned set*).
3.  **Preserve the Original Data Shape:** This transformation is an enhancement, not a replacement. You will reshape the value of the keys that currently hold the flat map (e.g., `"structure"`, `"context"`, `"result.nodes"`). Do not add new top-level keys like `"tree"`; instead, modify the existing ones to be hierarchical.
4.  **Ensure Consistency:** The same transformation logic must be applied consistently across all relevant tools. The key for nested children must always be `"children"`.

**Example Transformation:**

*   **From (Flat):**
    ```json
    { "structure": { "nodeA": {"parents": []}, "nodeB": { "parents": ["nodeA"] } } }
    ```
*   **To (Hierarchical):**
    ```json
    {
      "structure": {
        "nodeA": {
          "parents": [],
          "children": {
            "nodeB": { "parents": ["nodeA"], "children": {} }
          }
        }
      }
    }
    ```

This is not a simple task. It requires careful thought about how to build this transformation efficiently and how to handle various edge cases (e.g., graphs with multiple roots, empty results). We are entrusting you with this critical task because we need it done perfectly. Think through your implementation, write clean and reusable code, and test your logic to ensure that the output is always a valid and accurate hierarchical representation of the underlying data.

### Part 1 — Project overview (remote-mcp-server-authless) to execute the new objectives

Read this end-to-end before you begin. You are expected to think as long as necessary to ensure a correct, complete, high‑quality implementation. Do not rush. - No Supabase schema changes are required for this objective.

- A rule has been added in rule1.mdc: All MCP tool responses that return a collection of graph nodes must structure that collection as a nested, hierarchical object reflecting the parent‑child relationships, not as a flat map. The key for a node’s children is 'children'.
- This work is confined to the worker repo: remote-mcp-server-authless.

Purpose of this worker
- Implements the Model Context Protocol (MCP) server exposing graph tools to the AI assistant.
- Runs as a Cloudflare Worker (default export has a fetch handler; routes /sse, /mcp).
- Talks to Supabase to persist and version the single JSON graph document (id='main').
- Enforces the Graph Contract and guards data quality.

Key files and structure
- remote-mcp-server-authless/src/index.ts
  - Registers all tools with this.server.tool(name, zodSchema, handler).
  - Fetch handler mounts SSE (/sse, /sse/message) and MCP JSON RPC (/mcp).
  - CORS helpers and transcription passthrough omitted from scope.

Graph document model (persisted in Supabase)
- A single document (id='main') with:
  - nodes: Record<nodeId, Node>, where Node includes:
    - type: 'objectiveNode' (enforced)
    - label: string
    - status: 'not-started' | 'in-progress' | 'completed' (enforced)
    - parents: string[] (child→parent links; this is the source of truth)
    - optional: color, notes, percentage_of_parent, createdAt, scheduled_start/end, etc.
  - viewport and other metadata.

Enforcement and calculation helpers
- normalizeNode(nodeId, node):
  - Enforces type to objectiveNode; rejects invalid types.
  - Normalizes status to allowed enum; converts 'pending' to 'not-started' or throws on invalid.
- calculateTruePercentages(nodes):
  - Computes impact across the tree; uses parents links to derive contributions.
- Percentage “squishing”:
  - After patching, recalculates percentage_of_parent for affected parents when adding children.

Important tools (in index.ts)
- get_todays_context
  - Returns { success, current_date, score_context, context }
  - context currently is a flat subset map: { [nodeId]: Node } for today.
- get_graph_structure(start_node_id='main', depth=-1)
  - Returns { success, current_date, score_context, structure }
  - structure currently is a flat subset map of nodes reachable from start, according to depth traversal (following parents).
- patch_graph_document(patches: RFC6902 JSON Patch)
  - Applies the patch, re-normalizes/enforces, recalculates true percentages and child percentages where needed.
  - Returns { success, score_context, result, graph_document_version_id }
  - result is the full graph document; result.nodes is a flat map.
- Version tools (get_graph_document_version, set_graph_document_to_version, get_or_create_default_graph_version)
  - Return or set historical versions; return body is a JSON text field inside MCP content array.

What must change (high-level)
- Today, tools return node collections as flat maps. We will preserve all existing fields and data, but the values that hold collections of nodes must be reorganized to be hierarchical, to directly mirror parent→child relationships as the UI presents them.
- This improves the assistant’s reasoning by reducing its need to reconstruct hierarchy from parents arrays.

Scope of reshaping (only shape, not content)
- get_graph_structure:
  - structure must become a nested object: top-level keys are the roots within the returned subset (nodes with no parents in the subset), and each node includes children: { [childId]: NodeWithChildren } recursively.
- get_todays_context:
  - context must be reshaped the same way as structure, with roots selected as nodes having no parents in the subset.
- patch_graph_document:
  - result.nodes must be returned as a hierarchical map (roots are those with no parents), preserving all node properties but adding children exactly as above.
- Everything else remains the same (success/current_date/score_context/etc.), and we do not add “tree” siblings or extra fields—only reshape the existing collection keys.

Consistency of hierarchical form
- The children key is exactly 'children'.
- Use the existing parents arrays to determine children; do not compute or persist any children arrays in storage.
- Roots: a node has no parents in the subset being returned.
- Depth handling (get_graph_structure): the subset must first be selected exactly as it is now; then the hierarchy is formed over that subset (nodes beyond depth are excluded).
- If a node has no children within the subset, children is an empty object ({}).

Reliability and acceptance
- The outputs must be identical in content but reorganized in form; do not drop fields.
- Ensure the AI can immediately see structural relationships without scanning entire maps.
- Confirm formatting is stable, deterministic, and consistent across tools.
- Validate on realistic graphs; ensure large graphs do not cause stack overflows in recursion (use iterative build if needed).
- Keep responses as strings in the MCP content array (unchanged wrapping protocol).

Quality bar
- Think carefully about subset roots, ordering, and deterministic assembly.
- Reuse a single helper to build the hierarchical projection so behavior matches across tools.
- Test on 'main' graph and selections; verify correctness vs current UI inference.
- This must be done meticulously and correctly the first time.
